author: gcolvin
content:
Stupid questions --
1. Given a contract, is it possible to know the block number of the transaction that created it?
2. Given a contract created by another contract, is it possible to find the creator?

If the answers are yes I think we can do without EVM versioning for some purposes.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't *think* that information is stored anywhere.  Some clients *may* have that information available, but I don't think it is anywhere in consensus in a way that is easily accessible.

author: holiman
content:
1. Not in any easy way. For geth, you'd basically need to iterate through everything and trace
2. Same answer. (However, if you have a candidate, it's possible to verify that the candidate _is_ the creator)

author: axic3354
content:
The main complaint against evm versioning is just introducing it for the sake of introducing (or some perceived flexibility) is not worth it if we need to keep the old EVM alive. So a lot of the changes we tried to do by either fitting into the current framework (even if it is suboptimal) or trying to deprecate things by not breaking anything in a major way.

What I hope for is that with the new state expiry model there would be a very good disincentive to use old contracts ("epoch 0"), therefore adding evm versioning then means everyone would be incentivized to use that and to migrate to it. (One needs to read the state expiry document slated for today's call.)

author: samwilsn
content: Anyone know offhand why EIP-3 (`CALLDEPTH`) was withdrawn?

author: pipermerriam
content:
I believe that the call depth limit was effectively (or maybe entirely) removed by the 63/64th gas rules that were added in one of the early forks.

Also, I would imagine that it falls into similar categories to ORIGIN/GAS in that such an opcode would allow for a type of introspection into the execution environment that results in difficulties in maintaining backwards compatibility.
